column48: whose eye glistened greedily
column49: ‘at least
column50: as well as one can be when one is very hungry. But what is the matter with you? A fortnight ago you were as plump as heart could wish!’‘Quite so
column51: ’ replied the fox; ‘it would be unreasonable of me to object to your satisfying your appetite at my expense. But if the fox resigns herself to the sacrifice
column52: the mother offers you one last request.’‘You must know
column53: ’ said the fox
column54: ‘that in this village there is a rich man who makes in the summer enough cheeses to last him for the whole year
column55: and keeps them in an old well
column56: now dry
column57: in his courtyard. By the well hang two buckets on a pole that were used
column58: in former days
column59: to draw up water. For many nights I have crept down to the palace
column60: and have lowered myself in the bucket
column61: bringing home with me enough cheese to feed the children. All I beg of you is to come with me
column62: and
column63: instead of hunting chickens and such things
column64: I will make a good meal off cheese before I die.’

column1: All was silent in the village
column2: and not a light was to be seen but that of the moon
column3: which shone bright and clear in the sky. The wolf and the fox crept softly along
column4: when suddenly they stopped and looked at each other; a savoury smell of frying bacon reached their noses
column5: and reached the noses of the sleeping dogs
column6: who began to bark greedily.In about half an hour the dogs grew tired of barking
column7: or perhaps the bacon was eaten up and there was no smell to excite them. Then the wolf and the fox jumped up
column8: and hastened to the foot of the wall.‘I am lighter than he is
column9: ’ thought the fox to herself
column10: ‘and perhaps if I make haste I can get a start
column11: and jump over the wall on the other side before he manages to spring over this one.’ And she quickened her pace. But if the wolf could not run he could jump
column12: and with one bound he was beside his companion.‘Be careful
column13: or I shall scream
column14: ’ she snarled. And the wolf
column15: understanding all that might happen if the fox carried out her threat
column16: gave a signal to his companion to leap on the wall
column17: where he immediately followed her.Once on the top they crouched down and looked about them. Not a creature was to be seen in the courtyard
column18: and in the furthest corner from the house stood the well
column19: with its two buckets suspended from a pole
column20: just as the fox had described it. The two thieves dragged themselves noiselessly along the wall till they were opposite the well
column21: and by stretching out her neck as far as it would go the fox was able to make out that there was only very little water in the bottom
column22: but just enough to reflect the moon
column23: big
column24: and round and yellow.The wolf looked up
column25: and saw the bucket hanging there
column26: and with some difficulty he climbed into it. As he weighed at least four times as much as the fox the bucket went down with a jerk
column27: and the other bucket
column28: in which the fox was seated
column29: came to the surface.‘Ah
column30: traitor!’ cried the wolf
column31: howling with rage. But the fox was not there to hear this insult
column32: for she had gone off to a neighbouring fowl-house
column33: where she had noticed some fat young chickens the day before.‘Perhaps I did treat him rather badly
column34: ’ she said to herself. ‘But it seems getting cloudy
column35: and if there should be heavy rain the other bucket will fill and sink to the bottom
column36: and his will go up--at least it may!’Long ago a king and queen ruled over the islands of the west
column37: and they had one son
column38: whom they loved dearly. The boy grew up to be tall and strong and handsome
column39: and he could run and shoot
column40: and swim and dive better than any lad of his own age in the country. Besides
column41: he knew how to sail about
column42: and sing songs to the harp
column43: and during the winter evenings
column44: when everyone was gathered round the huge hall fire shaping bows or weaving cloth
column45: Ian Direach would tell them tales of the deeds of his fathers.So the time slipped by till Ian was almost a man
column46: as they reckoned men in those days
column47: and then his mother the queen died. There was great mourning throughout all the isles
column48: and the boy and his father mourned her bitterly also; but before the new year came the king had married another wife
column49: and seemed to have forgotten his old one. Only Ian remembered.On a morning when the leaves were yellow in the trees of the glen
column50: Ian slung his bow over his shoulder
column51: and filling his quiver with arrows
column52: went on to the hill in search of game. But not a bird was to be seen anywhere
column53: till at length a blue falcon flew past him
column54: and raising his bow he took aim at her. His eye was straight and his hand steady
column55: but the falcon’s flight was swift
column56: and he only shot a feather from her wing. As the sun was now low over the sea he put the feather in his game bag
column57: and set out homewards.‘I am setting it on you as crosses and as spells
column58: and as the fall of the year! That you may always be cold
column59: and wet and dirty
column60: and that your shoes may ever have pools in them
column61: till you bring me hither the blue falcon on which that feather grew.’‘If it is spells you are laying I can lay them too
column62: ’ answered Ian Direach; ‘and you shall stand with one foot on the great house and another on the castle
column63: till I come back again
column64: and your face shall be to the wind
column65: from wheresoever it shall blow.’ Then he went away to seek the bird
column66: as his stepmother bade him; and
column67: looking homewards from the hill
column68: he saw the queen standing with one foot on the great house
column69: and the other on the castle
column70: and her face turned towards whatever tempest should blow.

column1: On he journeyed
column2: over hills
column3: and through rivers till he reached a wide plain
column4: and never a glimpse did he catch of the falcon. Darker and darker it grew
column5: and the small birds were seeking their nests
column6: and at length Ian Direach could see no more
column7: and he lay down under some bushes and sleep came to him. And in his dream a soft nose touched him
column8: and a warm body curled up beside him
column9: and a low voice whispered to him:Between them they kindled a fire
column10: and ate their supper. Then Gille Mairtean the fox bade Ian Direach lie down as before
column11: and sleep till morning. And in the morning
column12: when he awoke
column13: Gille Mairtean said:‘The falcon that you seek is in the keeping of the Giant of the Five Heads
column14: and the Five Necks
column15: and the Five Humps. I will show you the way to his house
column16: and I counsel you to do his bidding
column17: nimbly and cheerfully
column18: and
column19: above all
column20: to treat his birds kindly
column21: for in this manner he may give you his falcon to feed and care for. And when this happens
column22: wait till the giant is out of his house; then throw a cloth over the falcon and bear her away with you. Only see that not one of her feathers touches anything within the house
column23: or evil will befall you.’So Ian Direach entered
column24: and tended so well and carefully all the birds and beasts
column25: that the giant was better satisfied than ever he had been
column26: and at length he thought that he might even be trusted to feed the falcon. And the heart of Ian was glad
column27: and he tended the blue falcon till his fathers shone like the sky
column28: and the giant was well pleased; and one day he said to him:‘For long my brothers on the other side of the mountain have besought me to visit them
column29: but never could I go for fear of my falcon. Now I think I can leave her with you for one day
column30: and before nightfall I shall be back again.’Scarcely was the giant out of sight next morning when Ian Direach seized the falcon
column31: and throwing a cloth over her head hastened with her to the door. But the rays of the sun pierced through the thickness of the cloth
column32: and as they passed the doorpost she gave a spring
column33: and the tip of one of her feathers touched the post
column34: which gave a scream
column35: and brought the giant back in three strides. Ian Direach trembled as he saw him; but the giant only said:‘Ah
column36: that is for you to discover.’ And Ian dared say no more
column37: and hastened down to the waste. There
column38: as he hoped
column39: he met his friend Gille Mairtean the fox
column40: who bade him eat his supper and lie down to sleep. And when he had wakened next morning the fox said to him:‘Let us go down to the shore of the sea.’ And to the shore of the sea they went. And after they had reached the shore
column41: and beheld the sea stretching before them
column42: and the isle of Dhiurradh in the midst of it
column43: the soul of Ian sank
column44: and he turned to Gille Mairtean and asked why he had brought him thither
column45: for the giant
column46: when he had sent him
column47: had known full well that without a boat he could never find the Big Women.‘Do not be cast down
column48: ’ answered the fox
column49: ‘it is quite easy! I will change myself into a boat
column50: and you shall go on board me
column51: and I will carry you over the sea to the Seven Big Women of Dhiurradh. Tell them that you are skilled in brightening silver and gold
column52: and in the end they will take you as servant
column53: and if you are careful to please them they will give you the White Sword of Light to make bright and shining. But when you seek to steal it
column54: take heed that its sheath touches nothing inside the house
column55: or ill will befall you.’So Ian Direach did all things as the fox had told him
column56: and the Seven Big Women of Dhiurradh took him for their servant
column57: and for six weeks he worked so hard that his seven mistresses said to each other: ‘Never has a servant had the skill to make all bright and shining like this one. Let us give him the White Sword of Light to polish like the rest.’Then they brought forth the White Sword of Light from the iron closet where it hung
column58: and bade him rub it till he could see his face in the shining blade; and he did so. But one day
column59: when the Seven Big Women were out of the way
column60: he bethought him that the moment had come for him to carry off the sword
column61: and
column62: replacing it in its sheath
column63: he hoisted it on his shoulder. But just as he was passing through the door the tip of the sheath touched it
column64: and the door gave a loud shriek. And the Big Women heard it
column65: and came running back
column66: and took the sword from him
column67: and said:

column1: At these words the heart returned again to Ian Direach
column2: and he gathered sticks and made a fire and ate with Gille Mairtean the fox
column3: and slept on the sand. At dawn next morning Gille Mairtean said to Ian Direach:‘I will change myself into a ship
column4: and will bear you across the seas to Erin
column5: to the land where dwells the king. And you shall offer yourself to serve in his stable
column6: and to tend his horses
column7: till at length so well content is he
column8: that he gives you the bay colt to wash and brush. But when you run away with her see that nought except the soles of her hoofs touch anything within the palace gates
column9: or it will go ill with you.’After he had thus counselled Ian Direach
column10: the fox changed himself into a ship
column11: and set sail for Erin. And the king of that country gave into Ian Direach’s hands the care of his horses
column12: and never before did their skins shine so brightly or was their pace so swift. And the king was well pleased
column13: and at the end of a month he sent for Ian and said to him:‘You have given me faithful service
column14: and now I will entrust you with the most precious thing that my kingdom holds.’ And when he had spoken
column15: he led Ian Direach to the stable where stood the bay colt. And Ian rubbed her and fed her
column16: and galloped with her all round the country
column17: till he could leave one wind behind him and catch the other which was in front. ‘I am going away to hunt
column18: ’ said the king one morning while he was watching Ian tend the bay colt in her stable. ‘The deer have come down from the hill
column19: and it is time for me to give them chase.’ Then he went away; and when he was no longer in sight
column20: Ian Direach led the bay colt out of the stable
column21: and sprang on her back. But as they rode through the gate
column22: which stood between the palace and the outer world
column23: the colt swished her tail against the post
column24: which shrieked loudly. In a moment the king came running up
column25: and he seized the colt’s bridle.‘Plainly I see that you have not done as I bid you
column26: nor will you ever do it
column27: ’ spoke Gille Mairtean the fox; ‘but I will help you yet again. for a third time I will change myself into a ship
column28: and we will sail to France.’And to France they sailed
column29: and
column30: as he was the ship
column31: the Gille Mairtean sailed where he would
column32: and ran himself into the cleft of a rock
column33: high on to the land. Then
column34: he commanded Ian Direach to go up to the king’s palace
column35: saying that he had been wrecked
column36: that his ship was made fast in a rock
column37: and that none had been saved but himself only.Ian Direach listened to the words of the fox
column38: and he told a tale so pitiful
column39: that the king and queen
column40: and the princess their daughter
column41: all came out to hear it. And when they had heard
column42: nought would please them except to go down to the shore and visit the ship
column43: which by now was floating
column44: for the tide was up. Torn and battered was she
column45: as if she had passed through many dangers
column46: yet music of a wondrous sweetness poured forth from within.‘Bring hither a boat
column47: ’ cried the princess
column48: ‘that I may go and see for myself the harp that gives forth such music.’ And a boat was brought
column49: and Ian Direach stepped in to row it to the side of the ship.To the further side he rowed
column50: so that none could see
column51: and when he helped the princess on board he gave a push to the boat
column52: so that she could not get back to it again. And the music sounded always sweeter
column53: though they could never see whence it came
column54: and sought it from one part of the vessel to another. When at last they reached the deck and looked around them
column55: nought of land could they see
column56: or anything save the rushing waters.‘It is a queen you will be
column57: ’ answered Ian Direach
column58: ‘for the king of Erin has sent me for you
column59: and in return he will give me his bay colt
column60: that I may take him to the Seven Big Women of Dhiurradh
column61: in exchange for the White Sword of Light. This I must carry to the giant of the Five Heads and Five Necks and Five Humps
column62: and
column63: in place of it
column64: he will bestow on me the blue falcon
column65: which I have promised my stepmother
column66: so that she may free me from the spell which she has laid on me.’By-and-by the ship sailed into a harbour on the coast of Erin
column67: and cast anchor there. And Gille Mairtean the fox bade Ian Direach tell the princess that she must bide yet a while in a cave amongst the rocks
column68: for they had business on land
column69: and after a while they would return to her. Then they took a boat and rowed up to some rocks
column70: and as they touched the land Gille Mairtean changed himself into a fair woman
column72: and said to Ian Direach
column73: ‘I will give the king a fine wife.’

column1: Now the king of Erin had been hunting on the hill
column2: and when he saw a strange ship sailing towards the harbour
column3: he guessed that it might be Ian Direach
column4: and left his hunting
column5: and ran down to the hill to the stable. Hastily he led the bay colt from his stall
column6: and put the golden saddle on her back
column7: and the silver bridle over his head
column8: and with the colt’s bridle in his hand
column9: he hurried to meet the princess.‘I have brought you the king of France’s daughter
column10: ’ said Ian Direach. And the king of Erin looked at the maiden
column11: and was well pleased
column12: not knowing that it was Gille Mairtean the fox. And he bowed low
column13: and besought her to do him the honour to enter the palace; and Gille Mairtean
column14: as he went in
column15: turned to look back at Ian Direach
column16: and laughed.In an instant Gille Mairtean the fox had sprung on his back
column17: and gave him such a bite that he fell down unconscious. Quickly the fox took his own shape again
column18: and galloped away to the sea shore
column19: where Ian Direach and the princess and the bay colt awaited him.‘I will become a ship
column20: ’ cried Gille Mairtean
column21: ‘and you shall go on board me.’ And so he did
column22: and Ian Direach let the bay colt into the ship and the princess went after them
column23: and they set sail for Dhiurradh. The wind was behind them
column24: and very soon they saw the rocks of Dhiurradh in front. Then spoke Gille Mairtean the fox:Joy filed the hearts of the Big Women when they beheld the bay colt led up to their door by Ian Direach. And the youngest of them fetched the White Sword of Light
column25: and gave it into the hands of Ian Direach
column26: who took off the golden saddle and the silver bridle
column27: and went down the hill with the sword to the place where the princess and the real colt awaited him.‘Now we shall have the ride that we have longed for!’ cried the Seven Big Women; and they saddled and bridled the colt
column28: and the eldest one got upon the saddle. Then the second sister sat on the back of the first
column29: and the third on the back of the second
column30: and so on for the whole seven. And when they were all seated
column31: the eldest struck her side with a whip and the colt bounded forward. Over the moors she flew
column32: and round and round the mountains
column33: and still the Big Women clung to her and snorted with pleasure. At last she leapt high in the air
column34: and came down on top of Monadh the high hill
column35: where the crag is. And she rested her fore feet on the crag
column36: and threw up her hind legs
column37: and the Seven Big Women fell over the crag
column38: and were dead when they reached the bottom. And the colt laughed
column39: and became a fox again and galloped away to the sea shore
column40: where Ian Direach
column41: and the princess and the real colt and the White Sword of Light were awaiting him.‘I will make myself into a ship
column42: ’ said Gille Mairtean the fox
column43: ‘and will carry you and the princess
column44: and the bay colt and the White Sword of Light
column45: back to the land.’ And when the shore was reached
column46: Gille Mairtean the fox took back his own shape
column47: and spoke to Ian Direach in this wise:‘Let the princess and the White Sword of Light
column48: and the bay colt
column49: remain among the rocks
column50: and I will change myself into the likeness of the White Sword of Light
column51: and you shall bear me to the giant
column52: and
column53: instead
column54: he will give you the blue falcon.’ And Ian Direach did as the fox bade him
column55: and set out for the giant’s castle. From afar the giant beheld the blaze of the White Sword of Light
column56: and his heart rejoiced; and he took the blue falcon and put it in a basket
column57: and gave it to Ian Direach
column58: who bore it swiftly away to the place where the princess
column59: and the bay colt
column60: and the real Sword of Light were awaiting him.So well content was the giant to possess the sword he had coveted for many a year
column61: that he began at once to whirl it through the air
column62: and to cut and slash with it. For a little while Gille Mairtean let the giant play with him in this manner; then he turned in the giant’s hand
column63: and cut through the Five Necks
column64: so that the Five Heads rolled on the ground. Afterwards he went back to Ian Direach and said to him:‘Saddle the colt with the golden saddle
column65: and bridle her with the silver bridle
column66: and sling the basket with the falcon over your shoulders
column67: and hold the White Sword of Light with its back against your nose. Then mount the colt
column68: and let the princess mount behind you
column69: and ride thus to your father’s palace. But see that the back of the sword is ever against your nose
column70: else when your stepmother beholds you
column71: she will change you into a dry faggot. If
column72: however
column73: you do as I bid you
column74: she will become herself a bundle of sticks.’Ian Direach hearkened to the words of Gille Mairtean
column75: and his stepmother fell as a bundle of sticks before him; and he set fire to her
column76: and was free from her spells for ever. After that he married the princess
column77: who was the best wife in all the islands of the West. Henceforth he was safe from harm
column78: for had he not the bay colt who could leave one wind behind her and catch the other wind
column79: and the blue falcon to bring him game to eat
column80: and the White Sword of Light to pierce through his foes?

column1: And Ian Direach knew that all this he owed to Gille Mairtean the fox
column2: and he made a compact with him that he might choose any beast out of his herds
column3: whenever hunger seized him
column4: and that henceforth no arrow should be let fly at him or at any of his race. But Gille Mairtean the fox would take no reward for the help he had given to Ian Direach
column5: only his friendship. Thus all things prospered with Ian Direach till he died.It was summer in the land of Denmark
column6: and though for most of the year the country looks flat and ugly
column7: it was beautiful now. The wheat was yellow
column8: the oats were green
column9: the hay was dry and delicious to roll in
column10: and from the old ruined house which nobody lived in
column11: down to the edge of the canal
column12: was a forest of great burdocks
column13: so tall that a whole family of children might have dwelt in them and never have been found out.It was under these burdocks that a duck had built herself a warm nest
column14: and was not sitting all day on six pretty eggs. Five of them were white
column15: but the sixth
column16: which was larger than the others
column17: was of an ugly grey colour. The duck was always puzzled about that egg
column18: and how it came to be so different from the rest. Other birds might have thought that when the duck went down in the morning and evening to the water to stretch her legs in a good swim
column19: some lazy mother might have been on the watch
column20: and have popped her egg into the nest. But ducks are not clever at all
column21: and are not quick at counting
column22: so this duck did not worry herself about the matter
column23: but just took care that the big egg should be as warm as the rest.This was the first set of eggs that the duck had ever laid
column24: and
column25: to begin with
column26: she was very pleased and proud
column27: and laughed at the other mothers
column28: who were always neglecting their duties to gossip with each other or to take little extra swims besides the two in the morning and evening that were necessary for health. But at length she grew tired of sitting there all day. ‘Surely eggs take longer hatching than they did
column29: ’ she said to herself; and she pined for a little amusement also. Still
column30: she knew that if she left her eggs and the ducklings in them to die none of her friends would ever speak to her again; so there she stayed
column31: only getting off the eggs several times a day to see if the shells were cracking--which may have been the very reason why they did not crack sooner.She had looked at the eggs at least a hundred and fifty times
column32: when
column33: to her joy
column34: she saw a tiny crack on two of them
column35: and scrambling back to the nest she drew the eggs closer the one to the other
column36: and never moved for the whole of that day. Next morning she was rewarded by noticing cracks in the whole five eggs
column37: and by midday two little yellow heads were poking out from the shells. This encouraged her so much that
column38: after breaking the shells with her bill
column39: so that the little creatures could get free of them
column40: she sat steadily for a whole night upon the nest
column41: and before the sun arose the five white eggs were empty
column42: and ten pairs of eyes were gazing out upon the green world.Now the duck had been carefully brought up
column43: and did not like dirt
column44: and
column45: besides
column46: broken shells are not at all comfortable things to sit or walk upon; so she pushed the rest out over the side
column47: and felt delighted to have some company to talk to till the big egg hatched. But day after day went on
column48: and the big egg showed no signs of cracking
column49: and the duck grew more and more impatient
column50: and began to wish to consult her husband
column51: who never came.‘Let me look at it
column52: ’ said the old neighbour. ‘Ah
column53: I thought so; it is a turkey’s egg. Once
column54: when I was young
column55: they tricked me to sitting on a brood of turkey’s eggs myself
column56: and when they were hatched the creatures were so stupid that nothing would make them learn to swim. I have no patience when I think of it.’‘Well
column57: I will give it another chance
column58: ’ sighed the duck
column59: ‘and if it does not come out of its shell in another twenty-four hours
column60: I will just leave it alone and teach the rest of them to swim properly and to find their own food. I really can’t be expected to do two things at once.’ And with a fluff of her feathers she pushed the egg into the middle of the nest.All through the next day she sat on
column61: giving up even her morning bath for fear that a blast of cold might strike the big egg. In the evening
column62: when she ventured to peep
column63: she thought she saw a tiny crack in the upper part of the shell. Filled with hope
column64: she went back to her duties
column65: though she could hardly sleep all night for excitement. When she woke with the first steaks of light she felt something stirring under her. Yes
column66: there it was at last; and as she moved
column67: a big awkward bird tumbled head foremost on the ground.

column1: There was no denying it was ugly
column2: even the mother was forced to admit that to herself
column3: though she only said it was ‘large’ and ‘strong.’ ‘You won’t need any teaching when you are once in the water
column4: ’ she told him
column5: with a glance of surprise at the dull brown which covered his back
column6: and at his long naked neck. And indeed he did not
column7: though he was not half so pretty to look at as the little yellow balls that followed her.When they returned they found the old neighbour on the bank waiting for them to take them into the duckyard. ‘No
column8: it is not a young turkey
column9: certainly
column10: ’ whispered she in confidence to the mother
column11: ‘for though it is lean and skinny
column12: and has no colour to speak of
column13: yet there is something rather distinguished about it
column14: and it holds its head up well.’‘It is very kind of you to say so
column15: ’ answered the mother
column16: who by this time had some secret doubts of its loveliness. ‘Of course
column17: when you see it by itself it is all right
column18: though it is different
column19: somehow
column20: from the others. But one cannot expect all one’s children to be beautiful!’‘You must go up and bow low before her
column21: ’ whispered the mother to her children
column22: nodding her head in the direction of the old lady
column23: ‘and keep your legs well apart
column24: as you see me do. No well-bred duckling turns in its toes. It is a sign of common parents.’The little ducks tried hard to make their small fat bodies copy the movements of their mother
column25: and the old lady was quite pleased with them; but the rest of the ducks looked on discontentedly
column26: and said to each other:‘Oh
column27: dear me
column28: here are ever so many more! The yard is full already; and did you ever see anything quite as ugly as that great tall creature? He is a disgrace to any brood. I shall go and chase him out!’ So saying she put up her feathers
column29: and running to the big duckling bit his neck.‘No; but he is so ugly and awkward no one can put up with him
column30: ’ answered the stranger. And though the duckling did not understand the meaning of the words
column31: he felt he was being blamed
column32: and became more uncomfortable still when the old Spanish duck who ruled the fowlyard struck in:‘Well
column33: you must feel quite at home here
column34: ’ said the old duck waddling off. And so they did
column35: all except the duckling
column36: who was snapped at by everyone when they thought his mother was not looking. Even the turkey-cock
column37: who was so big
column38: never passed him without mocking words
column39: and his brothers and sisters
column40: who would not have noticed any difference unless it had been put into their heads
column41: soon became as rude and unkind as the rest.At last he could bear it no longer
column42: and one day he fancied he saw signs of his mother turning against him too; so that night
column43: when the ducks and hens were still asleep
column44: he stole away through an open door
column45: and under cover of the burdock leaves scrambled on by the bank of the canal
column46: till he reached a wide grassy moor
